header.title: i

description.p: The module i provides short forms for some of the functions used by the graphical Debugger and some of the functions in the int module, the Erlang interpreter.
This module also provides facilities for displaying status information about interpreted processes and break points.

It is possible to attach to interpreted processes by giving the corresponding process identity only. By default, an attachment window pops up. Processes at other Erlang nodes can be attached manually or automatically.
By preference, these functions can be included in the module shell_default. By default, they are.

func.name: im() -> pid()
func.fsummary: Start a graphical monitor

desc.p: Starts a new graphical monitor. This is the Monitor window, the main window of the Debugger. All of the Debugger and interpreter functionality is accessed from the Monitor window. The Monitor window displays the status of all processes that have been/are executing interpreted modules.

func.name: ii(AbsModules) -> ok
ii(AbsModule) -> {module, Module} | error
ini(AbsModules) -> ok
ini(AbsModule) -> {module, Module} | error
func.fsummary: Interpret a module

desc.p: Interprets the specified module(s). ii/1 interprets the module(s) only at the current node, see int:i/1. ini/1 interprets the module(s) at all known nodes, see int:ni/1.

func.name: iq(AbsModule) -> ok
inq(AbsModule) -> ok
func.fsummary: Stop interpreting a module

desc.p: Stops interpreting the specified module. iq/1 stops interpreting the module only at the current node. inq/1 stops interpreting the module at all known nodes.

func.name: il() -> ok
func.fsummary: Make a printout of all interpreted modules

desc.p: Makes a printout of all interpreted modules. Modules are printed together with the full path name of the corresponding source code file.

func.name: ip() -> ok
func.fsummary: Make a printout of the current status of all interpreted processes

desc.p: Makes a printout of the current status of all interpreted processes.

func.name: ic() -> ok
func.fsummary: Clear information about processes executing interpreted code

desc.p: Clears information about processes executing interpreted code byt removing all information about terminated processes.

func.name: iaa(Flags) -> true
iaa(Flags, Function) -> true
func.fsummary: Set when and how to attach to a process

desc.p: Sets when and how to automatically attach to a debugged process, see int:auto_attach/2. Function defaults to the standard function used by the Debugger.

func.name: ist(Flag) -> true
func.fsummary: Set how to save call frames

desc.p: Sets how to save call frames in the stack, see int:stack_trace/1.

func.name: ia(Pid) -> ok | no_proc
func.fsummary: Attach to a process

desc.p: Attaches to the debugged process Pid. A Debugger Attach Process window is opened for the process.

func.name: ia(X,Y,Z) -> ok | no_proc
func.fsummary: Attach to a process

desc.p: Same as ia(Pid), where Pid is the result of calling the shell function pid(X,Y,Z).

func.name: ia(Pid, Function) -> ok | no_proc
func.fsummary: Attach to a process

desc.p: Attaches to the debugged process Pid. The interpreter will call spawn(Module, Name, [Pid]) (and ignore the result).

func.name: ia(X,Y,Z, Function) -> ok | no_proc
func.fsummary: Attach to a process

desc.p: Same as ia(Pid, Function), where Pid is the result of calling the shell function pid(X,Y,Z). An attached process is expected to call the unofficial int:attached(Pid) function and to be able to handle messages from the interpreter, see dbg_wx_trace.erl for an example.

func.name: ib(Module, Line) -> ok | {error, break_exists}
func.fsummary: Create a breakpoint

desc.p: Creates a breakpoint at Line in Module.

func.name: ib(Module, Name, Arity) -> ok | {error, function_not_found}
func.fsummary: Create breakpoints in the specified function

desc.p: Creates breakpoints at the first line of every clause of the Module:Name/Arity function.

func.name: ir() -> ok
func.fsummary: Delete all breakpoints

desc.p: Deletes all breakpoints.

func.name: ir(Module) -> ok
func.fsummary: Delete all breakpoints in a module

desc.p: Deletes all breakpoints in Module.

func.name: ir(Module, Line) -> ok
func.fsummary: Delete a breakpoint

desc.p: Deletes the breakpoint located at Line in Module.

func.name: ir(Module, Name, Arity) -> ok | {error, function_not_found}
func.fsummary: Delete breakpoints from the specified function

desc.p: Deletes the breakpoints at the first line of every clause of the Module:Name/Arity function.

func.name: ibd(Module, Line) -> ok
func.fsummary: Make a breakpoint inactive

desc.p: Makes the breakpoint at Line in Module inactive.

func.name: ibe(Module, Line) -> ok
func.fsummary: Make a breakpoint active

desc.p: Makes the breakpoint at Line in Module active.

func.name: iba(Module, Line, Action) -> ok
func.fsummary: Set the trigger action of a breakpoint

desc.p: Sets the trigger action of the breakpoint at Line in Module to Action.

func.name: ibc(Module, Line, Function) -> ok
func.fsummary: Set the conditional test of a breakpoint

desc.p: Sets the conditional test of the breakpoint at Line in Module to Function.

The conditional test is performed by calling Module:Name(Bindings), where Bindings is the current variable bindings. The function must return true (break) or false (do not break). Use int:get_binding(Var, Bindings) to retrieve the value of a variable Var.

func.name: ipb() -> ok
func.fsummary: Make a printout of all existing breakpoints

desc.p: Makes a printout of all existing breakpoints.

func.name: ipb(Module) -> ok
func.fsummary: Make a printout of all breakpoints in a module

desc.p: Makes a printout of all existing breakpoints in Module.

func.name: iv() -> atom()
func.fsummary: Current version number of the interpreter

desc.p: Returns the current version number of the interpreter. The same as the version number of the Debugger application.

func.name: help() -> ok
func.fsummary: Print help text

desc.p: Prints help text.

section.title: Usage
section.p: Refer to the Debugger User's Guide for information about the Debugger.
